paragraphs.text:
%md
# **WorldWideWeb**

by Anish Singh
blog site : [Zeppelin Notes](http://zeppelinnotes.blogspot.in)
[Image]

#### Introduction
**WorldWideWeb** is a notebook that explores web crawl data and performs analysis on that data to gain interesting insights. The data used for the analysis is open data made available by the
common crawl organization which provides web crawl data for free and open use. The common crawl organization builds and maintains an open repository web crawl data that can be  accessed  and
analysed by anyone. They have the web crawl data for the last seven years and the data is available in three formats : the WARC format, containing the raw crawl data, the WAT format, contain
-ing the metadata for the crawled data and the WET format, containing the text extracted from the crawled data. The WARC format has largely been used for analysis in this  notebook  and  the
other formats have been used as and when required. For the analysis and manipulation of the Warc format files, no tool other than the Warcbase library could have been more useful.  The  data
for only the month of May 2016 has been considered as the entire corpus is too large to be analysed at once, considering the fact that this notebook was running on a m4.xlarge EC2  instance.
The data for the month of May is divided into segments and only six segments have been considered, again due to the restricting capabilities of the machine used to design this notebook. More
information about the design of the notebook and choosing of the data sets may be found on the blogsite mentioned above.

This notebook uses Apache Spark for analysis of common crawl data and the visualization capabilities of Apache Zeppelin.

%sh
#this paragraph downlaods the common crawl datasets needed for analysis

#download the datasets for the first three segments of May
 wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/CommonCrawl/MayWarcSeg1.warc.gz "https://commoncrawl.s3.amazonaws.com/crawl-data/CC-MAIN-2016-22/segments/1464049270134.8/warc/CC-MAIN-20160524002110-00000-ip-10-185-217-139.ec2.internal.warc.gz"
 wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/CommonCrawl/MayWarcSeg2.warc.gz "https://commoncrawl.s3.amazonaws.com/crawl-data/CC-MAIN-2016-22/segments/1464049270134.8/warc/CC-MAIN-20160524002110-00001-ip-10-185-217-139.ec2.internal.warc.gz"
 wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/CommonCrawl/MayWarcSeg3.warc.gz "https://commoncrawl.s3.amazonaws.com/crawl-data/CC-MAIN-2016-22/segments/1464049270134.8/warc/CC-MAIN-20160524002110-00000-ip-10-185-217-139.ec2.internal.warc.gz"
 
#download the datasets for the last two segments of May
 wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/commonCrawl/MayWarcSeg4.warc.gz "https://commoncrawl.s3.amazonaws.com/crawl-data/CC-MAIN-2016-22/segments/1464056639771.99/warc/CC-MAIN-20160524022359-00242-ip-10-185-217-139.ec2.internal.warc.gz"
 wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/commonCrawl/MayWarcSeg5.warc.gz "https://commoncrawl.s3.amazonaws.com/crawl-data/CC-MAIN-2016-22/segments/1464056639771.99/warc/CC-MAIN-20160524022359-00243-ip-10-185-217-139.ec2.internal.warc.gz"
 wget -O ~/ZeppelinData/commonCrawl/MayWarcSeg6.warc.gz "https://commoncrawl.s3.amazonaws.com/crawl-data/CC-MAIN-2016-22/segments/1464056639771.99/warc/CC-MAIN-20160524022359-00244-ip-10-185-217-139.ec2.internal.warc.gz"

result.msg:
DepInterpreter(%dep) deprecated. Load dependency through GUI interpreter menu instead.
res0: org.apache.zeppelin.dep.Dependency = org.apache.zeppelin.dep.Dependency@d0cc05b

paragraphs.text:
//this paragraph loads the datasets in zeppelin for analysis
import org.warcbase.spark.matchbox._
import org.warcbase.spark.rdd.RecordRDD._

val mayWarcSeg1 = RecordLoader.loadArchives("/home/ubuntu/ZeppelinData/CommonCrawl/MayWarcSeg1.warc.gz", sc)        //load the data sets for the first three segments of May
val mayWarcSeg2 = RecordLoader.loadArchives("/home/ubuntu/ZeppelinData/CommonCrawl/MayWarcSeg2.warc.gz", sc)
val mayWarcSeg3 = RecordLoader.loadArchives("/home/ubuntu/ZeppelinData/CommonCrawl/MayWarcSeg3.warc.gz", sc)

val mayBegData = mayWarcSeg1.union(mayWarcSeg2).union(mayWarcSeg3)                     //combine the data for the first three segments of May

val mayWarcSeg4 = RecordLoader.loadArchives("/home/ubuntu/ZeppelinData/CommonCrawl/MayWarcSeg4.warc.gz", sc)        //load the data sets for the last three segments of May
val mayWarcSeg5 = RecordLoader.loadArchives("/home/ubuntu/ZeppelinData/CommonCrawl/MayWarcSeg5.warc.gz", sc)
val mayWarcSeg6 = RecordLoader.loadArchives("/home/ubuntu/ZeppelinData/CommonCrawl/MayWarcSeg6.warc.gz", sc)

val mayEndData = mayWarcSeg4.union(mayWarcSeg5).union(mayWarcSeg6)                     //combine the data for the last three segments of May

paragraphs.text:
%md
## 1. Domain Frequency
The domain frequencies as extracted from the web crawl data would be a good indicator of the presense of various domains on the web and the extent to which they are spread. This introductory
section attempts to examine the domain frequencies to get an idea about the domains that have been more prominent in the crawl data under consideration for both the introductory and the endi
-ng sections of May. The paragraph below first generates the data needed for the visualization (generates the frequency data) and the paragraphs that follow display the data. For the beginni
-ng period of May, we find that the domains : 'fangraphs.com', 'osnews.com', 'packages.ubuntu.com' and 'google.com' are on the top. 'fangraphs.com' is a site for baseball news and blog while
'osnews.com' is based on blogs and reports about products and companies in the computer industry. The remaining top two domains hold their positions for well understood reasons.

As for the ending sections of May, the domains change their relative positions with 'economist.com' taking the top position, followed by 'build.com', 'dailytech.com' and 'theday.com'.  These
websites too are news and blog sites with the 'economist.com' concerned with the economics of the world; 'dailytech.com' is again a news and blog site for the information about the  computer
industry; only 'build.com' is a site among the others that is not a news website and offers solutions for building homes and decor of houses. The websites that were at the top in the beginni
-ng have receeded to lower positions for the ending segments data.

> *More Frequency may get more Ad revenues*

Advertisement is undoubtfully one of the greatest sources of revenues on the web. Greater frequency of certain domains on the web indicates that they are comparatively more prominent than ot
-hers which may also help them with more ad revenues as more prominent domains will be able to draw more web traffic to their site. Some of the domains contain specifc content which can help
in targeted advertising. For example, 'fangraphs.com' shows content only about baseball and so it will attract people who are interested in the game and this fact could be used by  companies 
that manufacture and sell baseball equipment to target the ads to only those people. When I visited 'osnews.com', I got two ads : one for 'Aruba' cloud solutions and another for Dell XPS lap
-tops.

> *Domain Frequencies may help understand position on the web*

Domain frequencies may help understand the current position of a particular domain on the web. Domains having more frequencies have better current positions on the web and hence are able  to
draw more traffic to their website in comparison to any other webiste that displays content on the same topic. More prominent domains will have more ad revenues therefore frequency  data  is
an important tool of measuring a website's performance on the web. Once people working on a domain know the relative positions on the web, they can figure out what changes led to a  decrease
or increase in the traffic to their site and compare their website presentaiton against those that have more or less frequencies enabling them to get a measure of themselves and enhancing th
-eir chances of improvement. This can be noticed in the frequency data shown below, for the beginning segments, 'osnews.com' has been on top for news related to computer industry  while  for
the ending segments, 'dailytech.com' gained the top position in terms of the frequncies. Apart from other factors, this may be due recent changes in the websites and their presentation.

//this paragraph generates the data needed for visualization

val mayBegFreq = mayBegData.keepValidPages()                        //get the domain frequency data for the beginning sections of May
                           .map(r => ExtractDomain(r.getUrl))
                           .countItems()
                           .take(60)
                           
val mayEndFreq = mayEndData.keepValidPages()                        //get the domain frequency data for the ending sections of May
                           .map(r => ExtractDomain(r.getUrl))
                           .countItems()
                           .take(60)
                           
val mayBegFreqTbl = sc.parallelize(mayBegFreq).toDF().registerTempTable("MayBegFreq")
val mayEndFreqTbl = sc.parallelize(mayEndFreq).toDF().registerTempTable("MayEndFreq")

paragraphs.text:
%md
## 2. Analysis of the Site Link Structure

The analysis of site link structure would reveal important information about how the sites are linked and which websites benefit from being linked to others. The domain frequencies as indicated
in the bar charts above suggest that few of the websites tend to be more frequent or prominent than the others and other domains may benefit from these prominent ones if they have  their  links
placed on the websites of the prominent domains, a phenomena on the web referred to as the **last click attribution model** which is finding out which link did the user click before landing  on
a particular page. This is specially profitable for those websites that have their links placed on the most prominent domains. The paragraph below generates the visualization  data  needed  for
the sankey diagrams which would best represent the outlinks from these more popularly used domains and the others that benefit from them. The paragraphs that follow present the sankey  diagrams
themselves.

//this paragraph attempts to generate the data needed for site link structure analysis (the outlinks from the various most prominent domains)

import StringUtils._
import org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD
import org.warcbase.spark.archive.io.ArchiveRecord

def getSankeyRep(inputDom : RDD[ArchiveRecord]) : Array[String] = {                     //function to extract links from the crawl data for a particular domain
    
    inputDom.flatMap(r => ExtractLinks(r.getUrl, r.getContentString))                   //perform the series of extractions and filtering
            .map(r => (ExtractDomain(r._1), ExtractDomain(r._2)))
            .filter(r => (r._1.compareTo(r._2) != 0))
            .map(r => (r, 1))
            .reduceByKey((x, y) => x + y)
            .map(r => "[ '" + r._1._1 + "', '" + r._1._2 + "', " + r._2 + " ]")
            .take(10)
}

val mayBegLink1 = mayBegData.keepValidPages()                                           //generate the data for visualization for only 'www.fangraphs.com'
                            .keepDomains(Set("www.fangraphs.com"))
val mayBegLnkWt1 = "[" + getSankeyRep(mayBegLink1).mkString(",") + "]"                  //get the link data for 'fangraphs.com' in Sankey representation
                            
val mayBegLink2 = mayBegData.keepValidPages()                                           //generate the data for visualization for only 'www.osnews.com'
                            .keepDomains(Set("www.osnews.com"))
val mayBegLnkWt2 = "[" + getSankeyRep(mayBegLink2).mkString(",") + "]"                  //get the link data for 'osnews.com' in Sankey representation

val mayBegLink3 = mayBegData.keepValidPages()                                           //generate the data for visualization for only 'www.google.com'
                            .keepDomains(Set("www.google.com"))
val mayBegLnkWt3 = "[" + getSankeyRep(mayBegLink3).mkString(",") + "]"                  //get the link data for 'google.com' in Sankey representation

result.msg:

paragraphs.text:
%md
The diagrams below present the outlinks from the various sites that have huge web traffic inflows. The other sites that are linked to the these famous sites take advantage of the
phenomenon of **'random browsing'** by which a general user after staying on a website for some time will change the website that he/she is viewing. So users that are on these sites have a high
probability of changing to websites that contain their links on these pages. This probability of switching to a particular site increases with the number of times that a particular  webpage  is
mentioned on a source-page. For example, if a 'source-page' contains 5 links to 'destination-page1' and 2 links to 'destination-page2' then there is a higher probability of a viewer landing  on
'destination-page1' than on 'destination-page2'. These link frequencies have been measured as 'weights' and thickness of the links in the sankey diagrams is proportional to the weight if a link
on hovering the mouse over a particular link in the diagram, the exact weight value of the link is displayed. This helps us know about the websites that benefit the most out of the popular ones.

> *Sports site links more to other sports sites*

The sports site 'fangraphs.com' links more to other sports sites with the most frequent being 'hardballtimes.com' with a weight value of 500 which means that 500 mentions of the latter site was
found on the crawl data of 'fangraphs.com'. Few other sites that contain their links on 'fangraphs.com' are 'foxsports.com' and 'baseballinfosolutions.com' which are also sports sites.  A  good
amount of the traffic of 'fangraphs.com' may get deviated to these other sites. Furthermore, realizing that the importance of the site 'fangraphs.com' a lot of other domains may be under compet
-ition to have their names and links appear on the site 'fangraphs.com' and this brings advantage to the site itself as it may charge these other sites for keeping these names on its sites. Cha
rges may even vary for the sites that want to have more mentions of their links on 'fangraphs.com'. This gives a pretty good picture of the working of the web advertisement and website business
model.

> *Technology site links more to other technology sites*

The technology site 'osnewws.com' links more to other technology sites and to other video sites for videos that are embedded in the website or links to other videos for product  information  or
news about product launches. 'theverge.com' is another site that contains information about technology although it is more general than 'osnews.com', the important fact is  that  'theverge.com'
contains the maximum links or mentions on 'osnews.com', followed by 'h-online.com' and the others, however the weight values are not as much as they had been in the previous cases and differ on
-ly slightly but still the other sites do benefit by having their names mentioned on the 'osnews.com' and it may be a source of constant revenue for 'osnews.com' to put the names of these other
sites on its webpages.

> *Google links only to Google*

The last of the sankey diagrams in this section present the outlinks for 'google.com', the most used internet search service. We know that search is one of the most used services on the interne
-t and 'google' by far dominates this service. More and more people turn to 'google' for their search queries and millions of search queries are services every day which means that  the  search
service has an increasingly large number of visitors that are only monotonically increasing. To take advantage of this situation, as we find in the graphs below, the website links only  to  its
own domains with the most dominant being 'scholar.google.com', a website for scholarly articles, this is followed by 'drive.google.com' and 'mapa.google.com', google's cloud storage and map ser
-vices respectively. This sort of creates a positive feedback cycle and directs the viewers to these other services of 'google.com' with apparently the most used being 'scholar.google.com'  and
so the users keep surfing the web within the domain boundaries of 'google.com'. They may change the domains manually by typing another address in the address bar or through bookmarks. Further,
as we might have noticed 'google' displays advertisements as small frames embedded in its pages, so for users surfing around only on the domains of 'google.com' he will get to see more  ads  of
companies that have paid 'google' for displaying their ads. Through browser tracking and other optimizations, these ads get tailored to specific viewers depending on their  particular  browsing
history.

For advertisement being the most important source of revenues on the internet, we find that the content of the domains helps them get more web traffic. Also, web traffic specifically is more on
sites that contain content regarding sports, technology, news and ofcourse search services - the requirement to find almost anything on the internet.

paragraphs.title: Outlinks from 'fangraphs.com'
Outlinks from 'osnews.com'
Outlinks from 'google.com'

paragraphs.text:
%md 

### **Fact File**
![Doodle](http://www.google.com/logos/doodles/2016/holi-festival-2016-4796769118453760-hp2x.gif)

1. Google takes over 200 factors into account before delivering the correct search results for any query in a fraction of a second.

2. The company owns a bunch of domains that are common misspellings of 'Google' like 'Gooogle.com', 'Gogle.com', 'Googlr.com' and more.

3. There are more than 2 million googles searches per second.

4. In 2013, 91% of the revenues of 'Google.com' came from advertising alone.

5. Google's search index is more than 100 million gigabytes in size. It would take 100,000 one-terabyte personal drives to contain the same amount of data.

6. Google might be the only company with the explicit goal to REDUCE the amount of time people spend on its site. 

7. Google has photographed more than 5 million miles of road for its Street View maps.

8. Google has acquired 24 companies this year alone  that's about three companies a month.

result.msg:
Fact File

  1. Google takes over 200 factors into account before delivering the correct search results for any query in a fraction of a second.

  2. The company owns a bunch of domains that are common misspellings of 'Google' like 'Gooogle.com', 'Gogle.com', 'Googlr.com' and more.

  3. There are more than 2 million googles searches per second.

  4. In 2013, 91% of the revenues of 'Google.com' came from advertising alone.

  5. Google's search index is more than 100 million gigabytes in size. It would take 100,000 one-terabyte personal drives to contain the same amount of data.

  6. Google might be the only company with the explicit goal to REDUCE the amount of time people spend on its site.

  7. Google has photographed more than 5 million miles of road for its Street View maps.

  8. Google has acquired 24 companies this year alone that's about three companies a month.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## 3. Analysis of the Web Graph structure using GraphX 
This section examines the web graph structure of the web using the common crawl data and the GraphX libraries of Spark. We know that in random browsing, the probability that a web user/viewer
will land on a particular page is determined by the 'page rank' value of the page. Using the links contained in the pages of the crawl data, we first calculate the 'page rank' value of the pa
-ges. This gives the size value of the nodes that represent the individual pages and the links that they have to other pages. Visualization for the graph is accomplished using D3 libraries.

The paragraph below first generates the data needed for the visualization.

//this paragraph generates the visualization needed for web structure analysis println("""%html

Visualization of the Web Graph Structure

""")

result.msg: Visualization of the Web Graph Structure
